paragraphs.text: %md ## OML4R Data Transformation: One-Hot Encoding In this notebook, we demonstrate how to perform one-hot encoding using OML4R using the customer insurance lifetime value dataset, which contains customer financial information, lifetime value, and whether or not the customer bought insurance. The dataset `CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV` is generated by the `"OML Run-me-first"` notebook, which `MUST` be run before this notebook. --- ##### `IMPORTANT`: The `"OML Run-me-first"` notebook is available under the menu Templates -> Examples and is a pre-requisite to the current notebook. --- **Note**: If the user plans to use the in-database algorithms, one hot encoding is automatically applied for those algorithms requiring it. The in-databae algorithms automatically explode the categorical columns and fit the model on the prepared data internally. For more details, see Data Preparation for GLM Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
OML4R Data Transformation: One-Hot Encoding

In this notebook, we demonstrate how to perform one-hot encoding using OML4R using the customer insurance lifetime value dataset, which contains customer financial information, lifetime value, and whether or not the customer bought insurance.

The dataset CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV is generated by the "OML Run-me-first" notebook, which MUST be run before this notebook.

IMPORTANT: The "OML Run-me-first" notebook is available under the menu Templates -> Examples and is a pre-requisite to the current notebook.

Note: If the user plans to use the in-database algorithms, one hot encoding is automatically applied for those algorithms requiring it. The in-databae algorithms automatically explode the categorical columns and fit the model on the prepared data internally. For more details, see Data Preparation for GLM

Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.title: Get a proxy object to CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV and subset of columns
paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.sync(query = c("CUST_DF" = "SELECT * FROM CUSTOMER_INSURANCE_LTV"))
ore.attach()

CUST_CAT_DF <- CUST_DF[, c("CUSTOMER_ID", "MARITAL_STATUS", "STATE", "GENDER", "REGION")]

z.show(head(CUST_CAT_DF, 5))

CU15154                   	SINGLE	CA                        	M                         	West

paragraphs.title: Create function for one hot encoding
paragraphs.text:
%r 

encode <- function(DF, ids, col) {
  uniqueValues <- ore.pull(unique(DF[col])) # Get the unique values of column col
  RESULT <- cbind(ids, DF[col]) # RESULT begins as ids and col to be encoded

  # Rename columns
  col_index <- which(colnames(RESULT) == col)
  colnames(RESULT)[col_index] <- "target_col"
 
  # Add One Hot Encoded columns to RESULT
  for (x in 1:nrow(uniqueValues)){
    RESULT <- cbind(RESULT, new_col = ifelse(RESULT$target_col == uniqueValues[x,], 1, 0)) # Add encoded column
    # Rename encoded column
    index <- which(colnames(RESULT) == "new_col")
    colnames(RESULT)[index] <- paste(col, gsub(" ", "", uniqueValues[x,1]), sep='.')
  }
 
  # Now that One Hot Encoded columns have been added, remove original column
  RESULT <- RESULT[-c(col_index)]
 
  return(RESULT)
}

paragraphs.title: Apply one hot encoding to MARITAL_STATUS column and check the transformed data
paragraphs.text:
%r

rownames(CUST_CAT_DF) <- CUST_CAT_DF$CUSTOMER_ID # Ordering rows of CUST_CAT_DF before applying function

ONEHOT_DF <- encode(CUST_CAT_DF, CUST_CAT_DF['CUSTOMER_ID'], "MARITAL_STATUS")

z.show(head(ONEHOT_DF))

paragraphs.title: Apply one-hot encoding to all selected categorical columns
paragraphs.text:
%r

RES_DF <- CUST_CAT_DF["CUSTOMER_ID"]

for (col in colnames(CUST_CAT_DF)[-c(1)]){
  
  ONEHOT_DF <- encode(CUST_CAT_DF, CUST_CAT_DF["CUSTOMER_ID"], col)
  
  RES_DF <- full_join(RES_DF, ONEHOT_DF)
}

rownames(RES_DF) <- 1:nrow(RES_DF) # Renaming rows of RES_DF

z.show(head(RES_DF))
